titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I. VI:30. Saturday. The boys came home from school at eleven O’Clock, and I took them with me to London to see the Mint— We stopp’d at Craven Street and took up Mr Smith— The Mint is upon Tower Hill. They made some difficulty at letting us in.— They said Mr Wellesley Pole gave Cards only for Thursday’s. I mentioned that Mr Lawson had advised me to come this day. They said Mr Lawson had nothing to do with it. At last however a man was called and directed to shew us the works. He hurried us along through the different apartments, without absolute incivility, and with very little civility— There is only one Steam engine, with a thirty horse power. We saw the various operations of rolling the bars of cutting, heating, weighing, washing cleaning, and coining the blanks of half crowns and shillings— I had twice seen all the same works at the Mint at St. Petersburg. The workmen here were more numerous. The washing of the Blanks in vitriolic acid I had not seen in Russia. Our conductor told me, that they struck four hundred thousand pieces in a day— We walked back to Craven Street. Mr Coles called there He has lately arrived from France. Smith went with John and Charles to the Sans Pareil Theatre in the Strand. George went to Drury Lane— I dined with Count Palmella the Portuguese Ambassador 74. South Audley Street. Lord Castlereagh was to have dined there, but is confined to his house with a Cold and sore throat— The Earl of Harrowby, Lord Palmerston, and Admiral Berkley were there. Count Lieven and Poletica, Baron Fagel and his brother, Baron Rehausen, Count Caraman, Mr Planta, and some others, persons attached to the Portuguese Embassy— At table I sat next to Lord Harrowby, and had much conversation with him; chiefly on the subject of Government. Whigs and Tories. The rights of the People and the rights of Kings— He appeared disposed to appretiate highly the free and liberal parts of the British Constitution; but he spoke with the contempt of derision, about radical reform, annual parliaments and universal suffrage. Sneered at Tom Paine—spoke slightingly of Locke, and censured the phraseology of the Act of Parliament by which James the second was declared to have broken the compact between the king and People— He attempted an argument about the duty and obligation of obedience, binding upon the people— I asked him if he admitted Government to be an affair of compact, and told him I would not ask any other concession. He was not willing to admit it; nor prepared to deny it; and I forebore to press him. He finally said the People had a right to be well governed, and when they were not, it was not of much consequence what the rights of Government to their obedience might be. After dinner I returned to Craven Street. John & Charles soon after came in with Smith from the Play— I did not wait for George, but came home with them at One.

2. VII:30. The Boys went to the chapel, and I attended Church. Prayers for the second Sunday in Lent were read by Mr Milman, the Sermon was preached by Mr Wallington from Matthew XV:28. “Then Jesus answered and said unto her; O woman, great is thy faith: be it unto thee even as thou wilt. And her daughter was made whole from that very hour.” A text taken from the gospel of the day. After returning home I had visits from S. Hazard, the Consul at Antwerp, and from Coll. Aspinwall and J. M. Forbes— Hazard is returning to America. He says there is no business doing at Antwerp. That he cannot live there, and that if the Government will make no provision for Consuls he shall resign the place— He goes to-morrow, to embark at Liverpool for New-York. I spoke to Coll. Aspinwall about Grubb, with whom I find him much dissatisfied. He told me that my recommendation and Grubb’s poverty were the only reasons of his having kept him so long. I desired him not to keep him another hour on the ground of my recommendation. I had never intended to countenance misconduct in any man, and never would. He told me several things of Grubb, much to his discredit— They went away between four and five— I walked an hour before dinner. In the Evening John and Charles returned to School, and George came home drenched with rain.

3. VII: Received this morning a Note from Miss Clitherow enquiring if we continued in the intention of leaving this house which I answered. The day and evening were stormy, with frequent and heavy showers of rain. I walked an hour before dinner, in which I encountered two plenteous showers. Antoine went to London. My Journal absorbed the labour of the day. In the Evening I attempted in vain to read.

4. IV:15. Wrote despatch 73 to the Secretary of State, breakfasted early and went into London. Walked to Turnham Green where I was overtaken by the Carriage. At Craven Street I found there was a Letter from W. S. Clarkson to J. A. Smith, giving notice that he had remitted to James Maury at Liverpool, by direction of my brother, a Bill of Exchange payable to me. I went and looked at several houses in Holles Street, and at one in Cavendish Square, to be let— The Rents are ten and twelve guineas a week, and the house in Cavendish Square 500 guineas a year; and a barely decent house for a small family. I called at the House Agent Robins’s to enquire if it was to be let for a shorter term, but he asked four
hundred guineas for it for four Months, or what they call the Season. It is usually from the first of April to the last of July, that being the period when the town is most frequented. On returning to Craven Street, I looked over the house where my Office is kept, which is also now to be let and is offered to me at ten Guineas a week. I shall most probably take it, having determined to return home next Summer.— There was a Note from Count G. Caraman enclosing a Letter to be forwarded to Philadelphia— I called at Silvester’s and took the Seal for George— Went to the foreign Office in Downing Street, and enquired if he could inform me, what was the object of a Bill now pending in Parliament, respecting the number of Passengers in foreign Vessels. He did not know. I told him there had been so many obstacles thrown in the way of American Vessels about their passengers, and I had been so unsuccessful in my applications to remove them, that on seeing in the Newspapers a Notice of this Bill, I was apprehensive it would raise new embarrassments, and wished to know its purport, and to enquire if some clause could not be introduced into it, at least to facilitate the means for the American Consul to send home destitute American Seamen. He sent to Mr Robinson to enquire what the intention of the Bill now before the house of Commons was; but Robinson was gone to the house, and Hamilton promised to write me the purport of the Bill. I pressed upon him the singularity of my position receiving from this Government one day the most urgent requisitions to send home to the United States all the Americans found here in distress, and the next day refusals of every accommodation to enable the American Consul to send them home. He said the requisitions to send them away were mere circular Letters sent to all the foreign Ministers, in the same words, adopted no doubt from a Letter from Lord Sidmouth’s Office, and founded altogether upon representations from the Lord Mayor. It was merely an invitation, of which the foreign Ministers were not obliged to take any notice at-all. Or they might say if they pleased that their Governments would not charge themselves with providing for their Countrymen who came here. I told him I had viewed the application in a very different, and more serious light, and had taken every possible means of complying with the requisition— I mentioned the delays which had interposed before the Consul could obtain the permission for the last transport to be dispatched; and the restrictions which finally limited the number of her Passengers, so that finally ten men who were sent on board, and ready to go with her, were turned back upon the Consul’s hands. The refusal to allow the Masters of American Vessels to take each five or six of these destitute Seamen, without reckoning five tons of the ship’s burthen, and abridging proportionably the number of profitable passengers, they may take. I complained of the inequality which this occasioned between British and American Vessels. The British not being bound to take any destitute American Seamen— He said British Vessels were obliged in like manner to take destitute British Seamen in our Ports— But I observed they were not subject to any limitation of the number of their Passengers. He said our Masters of Vessels were required to take our Seamen, by our own Laws, which the British Government could not controul. That we were not obliged to send our Seamen to America; we might send them any where else; where we pleased— That returns had been made to Lord Bathurst’s Office of all the Passengers that had gone from England in American Vessels in the course of the last year, and the number was very small. I said that was a proof how unnecessary all these restrictions were— He thought it was a proof that the regulations could not affect any considerable American interest, and therefore there could be no cogent motive for altering the Law— It is curious to observe to what shifts of argument these people resort, rather than candidly to come out with their real reasons and motives. Hamilton asked me, if British Seamen did not apply to be sent to the United States upon pretence of being Americans— I told him there were such cases, but the Consul always rejected them when he could ascertain the attempt at fraud— That I had suggested this difficulty in a Note to Lord Castlereagh, when he sent me the first requisition to send home all the destitute American Seamen; and had desired that this Government, should take upon itself the scrutiny, and specifically point out who were the Americans. But to this proposal I had received no answer— It was evident from the tenour of Hamilton’s Conversation, that the restrictions upon the carrying of Passengers will be increased, and in no respect relaxed. I left him, and returned to Craven-Street, and thence home. I found a Letter from Jas. Maury, enclosing a second Bill of Exchange for £877:10. Sterling, at sixty days sight, drawn at New-York 27. January, by Jonathan Ogden, upon Messrs Bolton and Ogden at Liverpool, payable in London, to me or my order; accepted 28 February, payable at Jos. Denison Esqr & Co. Mr
Maury writes that he had received the Bill from W. S. Clarkson, with a request that he would procure its acceptance and forward it to me— I gave George his Seal. He is unwell with a severe cold, and sore breast, and kept house this day. The Morning was fine; but there was a heavy storm of wind and rain again in the Evening. [symbols]

5. V:45. Received a Note from Miss Clitherow requesting me to send her the inventory of the furniture in the house, and that a Servant of Lady William Seymour’s might be admitted to inspect the kitchen utensils. I answered the Note, and sent the Inventory, and the woman came and saw the kitchen— I also wrote a Letter to Mr Maury at Liverpool— Walk before dinner through Sion House Park and Isleworth; musing on our approaching departure, and scenes to which I shall bid a last adieu— George in the Evening was reading Davis’s Life of Garrick— My wife rode out—the first time for a fortnight— George has a bad Cold and Cough.

6. IV:45. Finished a Letter to Jos: Hall of Boston which I began some days since, and immediately after breakfast went to London. Attended the Prince Regent’s Levee, and presented General Boyd. Mr Storer had concluded not to be presented, and Mr Coles not this time. The Prince spoke very graciously to General Boyd and much to his satisfaction. The General Levee was very numerously attended; and many Addresses were presented; some for retrenchment and reform, and the others to congratulate the Prince upon his escape, from the barbarous and traitorous, bullet and potatoe-plot and outrage. The presenters of many of the Addresses of this last description were knighted— I had short Conversations with many of the persons attending the Levee— The Spanish Ambassador, Fernan Nuñez, asked me if Congress had passed the Bill to prohibit the sale of armed Vessels by the Citizens of the United States, to the South American Insurgents— I had not heard. He said it was of great importance that it should pass— Lord Holland told me they considered their division in the House of Lords, against the Bill for suspending the Habeas Corpus Act, as a remarkably strong one. They mustered with their proxies 35 votes, against about 156—not one to four. Lord Erskine asked me, if I had seen his late publication; a sort of political Romance, entitled “Armata”—in form, an imitation of Gulliver’s Voyage to Lilliput, but in fact a review of the History of England, during the last half Century— I had bespoken the Book, but had not yet received it— He said he had given very freely his opinion there, both of the American revolutionary War, and of the French War. He was determined that his opinion upon both those subjects should go recorded to posterity— People might say it was damn’d Nonsense, but when, by whatever course of Events it happened that a man had sat upon the woolsack his opinions would have some weight with posterity.— I told him it needed not his seat upon the woolsack to give weight to his opinions. He said Sidmouth had told him he had read his Armata, and although there were many things in which they had differed, he admired many things in this book— It was a curious observation to me, to see a man of Erskine’s Powers, taking pride in the Admiration of Lord Sidmouth— Erskine said he had given them a trimming for the American and French Wars. Now there was not much diversity of Opinion about the first; but he had not the least doubt that if this Country had not gone to War with France, Louis the 16th. would have been at this day living; and King. He said that he himself had drawn up the French judicial Code— He had been five Months a member of the Committee for the Administration of Justice, and had worked for them the whole time, almost night and day. He had drawn up the whole system in English—and the simple translation from his work had been adopted— I took it that he spoke of the period under what was called the Constituent Assembly— I spoke to Lord Melville, and mentioned to him the terms of our new arrangement with Algiers; with which he expressed himself to be very well satisfied. The Earl of Harrowby, in a good humoured manner told me that he thought our Conversation at Count Palmella’s the other day, would make a figure in print, as a political dialogue; though his part of it, would shew to very little advantage. I told him, I was afraid if it should be printed, it would be thought to have an inflammatory tendency.— He said No—and that if due allowance was made for the situations of the respective Speakers, very little difference of principle would be found between us. He then recurred to France again; and said that Monsieur, Gallatin, he begged his pardon, Mr Gallatin, had spoken to him last Summer, with great contempt of the French Notions of Liberty— I said it seemed to me that the French were unable to combine all the simple ideas that were essential to constitute the complex idea of Liberty. They had for instance never been able to realize the principle of the Habeas Corpus Act— I considered this principle, as completely carried into effect by practice to be the only distinguishing feature of Liberty possessed by the British, over the other Nations of Europe; because in it was included the Liberty of the Press; which could not co-exist, with a power of arbitrary imprisonment. He said he thought it not the only distinct feature of British Liberty; because there was the immense, the overbearing power of Public Opinion; which was such that a British Government, even possessing the power of arresting individuals, must exercise it with such extreme caution and reserve, that it was scarcely any power at-all.— I admitted the force of public opinion, but said it was not peculiar, to this Country.— It was as great in France, and indeed all over Europe. And
indeed on the Continent was the only controul against the abuse of power, by the Governments. He said it was true: within the last forty years Public Opinion had risen up, and become the Queen of the World— It was the Dominion of the Newspapers. He agreed with me, as to the great value of the principle of the Habeas Corpus Act; but he also believed that its efficacy and its value depended entirely upon its being occasionally, and upon particular emergencies suspended. He did not know whether this would apply to America, But here, he was convinced it would unless occasionally suspended, operate not to the preservation, but to the destruction of public Liberty— I told him I had once as a Senator of the United States, voted for the suspension there, in the case of Burr’s conspiracy— The Senate had unanimously passed the Bill; but it was thrown out by the House of Representatives, and we had got along without it— He asked me what had been the object of Burr’s Conspiracy. I said it had been twofold— One a military project against Mexico. The other a plan to break up the Union of the States, and set up a Government of his own at New-Orleans; drawing as many of the Western States into it as he could— He enquired what had become of Burr, and whether he was not a man of considerable talents. I said he certainly possessed talents; and was now living in New-York, in obscurity. Recurring again to France he said he had been at Paris at the time of the first restoration of Louis 18. and again last year, in the midst of the party struggles between the Ultra-royalists and the ministerialists. And it was strange to observe the ultra’s, at the last period contending against a mere remnant proposed by the ministers of a restrictive law, which but the year before had been enacted by the ultra’s themselves. The king had granted him a private Audience; and the first question he had asked him was, whether he had read Chateaubriand’s new pamphlet? It was only two days after it had been suppressed by the King’s Authority. He therefore had answered the king that he had paid too much respect to his Majesty’s laws to have read the Book yet; but that he had it, and should soon read it. The king told him that Chateaubriand might have attacked his ministers and their measures, if he thought proper— They were fair subjects of discussion— But when he insinuated the personal duplicity of the king himself it was impossible for him to overlook it; or to avoid manifesting his displeasure— Lord Harrowby added that the conduct of the ultra-royalists, was indeed very extraordinary, but it was an exact counterpart of the latter portion of Sir Robert Walpole’s Administration in this Country, when all the motions in Parliament in favour of Liberty were made by the Jacobites and the Tories.— I spoke to Earl Bathurst of the state of things in South America; and of a petition presented a few days since by Mr Sharp, to the House of Commons, from one Englishman named Davison, complaining of having suffered torture by the thumb-screw, under the tyranny of the Haytian black King Henry: I said it gave a very different impression of that person’s government, from that which I had received from Mr Prince Saunders. Lord Bathurst said Davison had been to him, and shewn him his thumbs— They were indeed somewhat flattened, but did not appear to have suffered essential injury. The charge against him was that he had written politics in a professedly commercial Letter; and he certainly had mentioned the failure of an expedition of Christophe’s, without any comment indeed, but in such a manner as to shew that he was pleased with the failure— As to the South-American Affairs, he said the wars there appeared interminable. Neither party could obtain any permanent advantage over the other. It was very clear that Morillos would not even be able to maintain his own advantages without further reinforcements. While the Prince Regent was going round the Levee-room, Lord Castlereagh came up to me, and told me that he should soon wish to have some Conversation with me— I said I should be at his service at any hour that he would appoint. He replied that he would give me notice; he hoped in a few days; and that he should be authorized to discuss with me, at least the commercial part of the subjects I had proposed. But now he was incessantly harrassed with business, more than at any other period of his life— As to the afternoon and evening, he had been accustomed to be then occupied; but now the mornings were also absorbed, and he could only step from one Committee-Room to another— I introduced General Boyd to him. The Earl of Westmorland, also spoke to me, and as he usually does was entering into the most prominent topics of the day, but some person came and called him away. He was making enquiries of me about our methods of conducting Elections in America, and asked if we allowed universal suffrage. I told him not altogether— In some of the States the right of voting was
confined to freeholders, but in most of them it was universal, or extended to all who paid direct taxes, which was nearly the same thing. But even where the right of suffrage was universal, the elections were in general orderly. Riots seldom happened, and those only in the large Cities, such as New-York. We found nothing impracticable in universal suffrage, though I had observed it was considered here that it would be so in this Country— He said he did not know that it would be impracticable—but it would be a Revolution. England would be no longer England with it; for with a House of Commons so constituted, no other branch of the Government could subsist— I said I believed with him that it would be a Revolution; but how far it would extend I was not intimately enough acquainted with the practical construction of the Government to foresee— He said the Revolution would be total; and as it is, said he, it is doubtful whether we shall be able to save it. The popular power in this Country has increased and the power of the Crown has diminished within the last forty years enormously. This is the Ministerial doctrine of the day— I intimated a doubt of its correctness—remarked the power of the Crown over the house of Peers, three fourths of which have been created in the present reign— The influence of Official Patronage in the House of Commons, and in the Army and Navy— He said the Army and Navy were nothing, or next to nothing to the Crown— The Patronage was that of the Ministries, as they came on in succession. The influence of Offices, in the House of Commons, was much less than it had formerly been. In the house of Lords it was scarcely any thing; for the few Offices held by Peers were so small either in power or emolument to be no object at all of pursuit or desire to a Peer— The House of Peers had now become so numerous that they were much less under the influence of the Crown than formerly; they were created in fact not by the crown, but by the Ministers; and when once created were altogether independent of the Crown, which could not take the Peerage away: I thought still there was a sense of personal obligation, to the king, weighing more or less upon all the Peers created by him; but he said no—nothing at all. I said there was at least a sense of Common interest—a conviction that the dignity of the Peerage could not exist without that of the crown. That he said was some thing: And then I noticed the great influence of the Peers, in the House of Commons— Oh! yes! that very fortunately was great; and that was the only thing that could maintain the Constitution— For if once the house of Lords should take a wrong turn there would be no remedy. The partizans of Revolution had changed their point of attack— Formerly, it was against the Crown; but now they had turned against the House of Commons; but their object remained the same— Here, much to my regret our Conversation was interrupted— Between four and five O’Clock we left the Levee-Room, before the General Levee was over— On returning to Craven-Street I found Captain Upton of the British Navy; who wished to have a deed proved before me; of an Estate in the State of New-York— I appointed next Tuesday, between two and four O’Clock for that purpose. I sent several packages to Coll. Aspinwall’s Office to go, by the Galen, Captain Tracy to Boston; with a Note to the Consul— Returning home a Gentleman riding on horseback, knocked at the glass of my Carriage-door, and on my stopping, complained that my Coachman had startled his horse, and exposed him to danger, and then laughed at him— I assured him it must have been unintentional, as my Coachman was a quiet, sober man, incapable of insulting or willingly injuring any one— He strenuously insisted it was so— I said I would then make enquiry as soon as I should get home, into the Circumstances— He said there was no occasion for enquiry as he assured me it was so— I asked the favour of his name— He said Ponsonby; and he hoped I would at least reprimand the man. I promised him I certainly should if he deserved it. As soon as I got home I made enquiry how the accident had happened— It was at the short turning of a Street— The Gentleman’s horse had started on suddenly meeting those of my Carriage. But he suffered no injury, and the insult was imaginary. Robert says it was Mr Ponsonby, the Opposition Leader in the House of Commons, and Ex-Chancellor of Ireland— As I was coming home I read Southey’s Poem of Wat Tyler. The boys dined at home.

7. VIII:15 I was somewhat unwell yesterday, and once up in the Night, which occasioned my rising very late this Morning, and also a feeling of languor and dissipated Spirits the whole day so that I could write very little. Mr Watmough came out on a visit, with Henry Jonathan Williams, a son of the late General Jonathan Williams, who brought me a Letter of Recommendation from S. Ewing of Philadelphia— He has been some time in Scotland where the Relations of his mother reside. I walked to Hanwell and Ealing before dinner— George is suffering, with a severe Cough.

8. VI:30. Having determined to remove shortly from the house where we now reside, and to return to the United States in the course of the ensuing Summer, I was employed this morning in having one large box of my Books packed up; after which I went alone to London. It was four O’Clock when I came to the Office, and I was scarcely an hour there. Messer the Coachmaker called and Brock, the man of the Picture Frames, who had brought and left a Letter of explanation about them from Leslie— I walked to the Strand 192 for Cobbett’s Register, and in the Strand took from a hawker, number 2 of the [“]Republican,” a weekly two penny Paper, signed and printed by a man named Sherwin: it is an imitation of Cobbett, but mere declamation against the Court and Courtiers.— The title is bold, and the poor creature who was hawking them seemed ready to skulk as if he was afraid of being taken up and sent to prison. I read it as I was returning home— On returning home, I received two Letters from Coll. Aspinwall
and one from J. B. Church who is acting as American Consul at Cork, without a Commission. I left them on my table and forgot to read them this Evening. George has been this day confined to the house with his cough.

9. VI:45. George continues confined to the house. I attended Church alone. Prayers for the third Sunday in Lent were read by Mr Wallington; and the Sermon was preached by Mr Milman; from Hebrews II.18. the remnant of the discourse the first part of which he delivered this day fortnight— When I came home I found a Letter from R. Sharp; with a Card from his partner Mr Boddington, 31. Upper Brook Street; and an invitation to dine with him next Saturday. There came also Cards from Mrs and Miss Cowell, and an invitation to a musical party for the 18th.— Ellen, Laura and Charlotte Nicholas paid a visit to Mrs Adams; and invited us to a musical party at the Doctors on the 27th. when there is to be an Oratorio, at Isleworth Church in the Morning— I walked before dinner to Brentford, and through Sion House Park.

10. VI:45. Packed up this Morning a second box of Books, which left me little time for writing. General Boyd, and Messrs. Astor, Coles, D’Arcy, Forbes, Hollins, Pinkney, Smith, Storer, Talmadge and Watmough dined with me— Messrs. Bostwick, Buchanan and Williams, (H. J.) were invited, but sent excuses; as did Mr Sergeant, whose apology was brought by Mr Watmough— He was obliged to be in London this Evening upon his business.— My wife and George were both so unwell that they could not dine with us. Smith brought me out a Letter from J. Maury— The Company left me soon after ten.

11. VI:45. I wrote to Coll. Aspinwall, and sent him an order for £500 on the Baring’s. Wrote also to J. Grubb— Came to London with my wife, and took our Lodgings at N. 28 Craven Street, where we propose to stay till next Sunday Morning. We brought with us the two footmen, and two Servant Maids— Captain Upton of the British Navy, came with his friend Captain Shannon, also of the Navy, who proved according to a Law, of the State of New-York, before me, a conveyance by Lease and Release, of certain real Estate within that State— There were duplicates both of the Lease and Release— The Lease was executed by ten persons, and the release by twelve. Captain Shannon had witnessed the Execution by them all— The forms of the Certificates to be given by me had been drawn up, by Peter A. Jay. They declared that the witness was duly sworn, and deposed to the facts. I administered the Oath to Captain Shannon, considering that the authority for that purpose was given by implication in the New-York Statute; though I doubted whether by the general powers of my Office, I had the authority to administer an Oath to a British Subject— After they were gone, Dr Platt came in; and after him, Mr Rotch who told me he should in the course of a few days return to Dunkirk, where many years ago, he was for some time settled. And he is desirous of obtaining the Appointment of American Consul there. I promised him any assistance that I can give, to assist him in the attainment of his object. He went with me to the Corner of Bouverie Street where I left him; and went and dined with the Lord Mayor at the Mansion House. I was punctual at the appointed hour, half past five; and was the first there. It was a dinner to the Aldermen and their Ladies: and the Duke of Sussex, the Earl and Countess of Darnley, Lord Erskine, Lord Arthur Hill, Captain D’Este, Sir Charles and Lady Flint, and some others were there. Lord Darnley came only at the Dessert, having been engaged at a debate in the house of Lords, upon a question moved by the Earl of Grosvenor for abolishing Sinecures. The Lord Mayor had proposed to omit giving the usual Easter Monday dinner the present year, in Consideration of the Distresses of the Country, and to distribute among the charitable Institutions of the City, the sum of £1000 usually expended upon this Entertainment. He wrote a Note to each of the Aldermen, requesting his opinion upon this proposal, and then submitted it to them at a Court of Aldermen— But they unanimously declined giving any opinion, upon the question, as involving the antient usage and the dignity of the City, which as Miss Wood observed to me was giving an opinion in the very act of declining to give one. She said it was a subject upon which they were very sore— The Lord Mayor told the Duke of Sussex that he had had a list made out of all the members of both Houses of Parliament, who had voted against the suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act, and had sent them all Cards for the dinner, and to no others. So that if they would come, it would serve as a Memento to the Ministers. The Duke said they would come— He would take care they should come. I led Miss Wood down to dinner, and sat next to her at Table; by which means I was seated lower down than my place should have been, but for my own satisfaction, I could not have been more agreeably seated. After the Ladies retired, the
Lord Mayor called me up next to him— The party was less numerous than, any that I had met before at that place: not more than forty persons, and with less formality than usual. It was however impossible to escape the tax of toasting the healths of persons present, and the speeches to return thanks—but they were short and unpretending; in the mere style of conviviality— I went through this ceremony like the rest— The Lord Mayor, in naming me, alluded to the expectation of my early departure; and the Duke of Sussex, spoke of me in a very flattering and complimentary manner; which I answered with as little confusion and as few words as I could— There was an Evening party after dinner, and dancing. There I met Sir William Beechey and Mr Reeves— I told Reeves I would shew him some papers concerning Crosby’s case— Captain D’Este told me he was going to Canada, with Mr M’Gillivray, a Gentleman, at the head of the North-West Company— He also gave some hint as if he had thoughts of settling himself in America; being here he said in a very different rank of life from that in which he might be expected to move; and having all his prospects in life already blasted.— I encouraged him to hope for better times— Between eleven and twelve, I returned to Craven-Street, where we are to lodge until next Sunday.

12: VI:30. The Morning was much unoccupied, as a removal usually breaks up the habitual course of my employments. There was a curious meeting at my Office, of Mr John Reeves, and of Dr Cooke the chaplain in our Navy, at my Office. Reeves came to look at the papers in Crosby’s case; of which I had here only a general Statement— Cooke came to tell me that he had engaged his passage, and should sail in a few days for New York— About the year 1793. Cooke had been prosecuted at Cambridge, and convicted of seditious words, and Reeves about the same time, was the founder of the loyal associations all over the kingdom, against Republicans and Levellers. He was shortly after employed and very active in the prosecutions of persons charged with seditious practices— Cooke began by saying (not knowing Reeves) that since the suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act, and the revival of all the measures of rigour and restriction of the period when he had suffered; he was extremely anxious to get away from this Country, and safely landed in America— For there were so many rascally Spies about, there was no knowing what they would swear against a Man, and he could not feel himself secure of not being from one hour to another thrown into prison.— This immediately roused Reeves’s curiosity; who asked Cooke, if he was an American born— No, Sir, said Cooke I am an Englishman born; but have resided upwards of twenty years in America— I came over here some Months since, to see once more the friends yet surviving of those I had left behind, and am now returning to America; for a burnt Child dreads the fire— Then you have been a burnt Child, said Reeves— That I have, replied Cooke— Two rascally Spies, swore that I had said I meant to keep the 30th. of January not by going to Church; but by dining upon a Calve’s head. That I thought the English Nation had done right in cutting off Charles the first’s head, because he was a tyrant: that if other kings and emperor’s of our own times acted as tyrants, he thought their heads should be cut off; and if George the third should ever become such a tyrant as Charles the first had been, he would deserve to lose his head in the same manner.— But you was acquitted? said Reeves— No Sir— I went to Jail, and lay there three Months: and but for the intervention of a friend, I should have lain there two years. At the end of three Months however I was discharged, and that score being settled, I came and took a house in London. Why, said Reeves, I must have you upon my black Book— Cooke looked up, and I said to him, this is Mr Reeves— I dare say you have Sir, said Cooke; and I am pretty sure it was you, who drew up the Indictment against me— Reeves asked him if he had been tried at the Assizes, or at the Quarter Sessions. He answered at the Assizes and asked Reeves if he did not remember a man by the name of Portlock; he said he did not— Cooke then said he was by no means ashamed of having undergone that trial, and related an occurrence which had happened a few Months afterwards at a trial before Lord Kenyon at the Old Bailey; it was a civil Action between two parties, in which he Cooke was subpoena’d as a witness, and his evidence was so material that it decided the cause— When he had given his testimony Mr Mingay who was counsel for the party against whom it operated, began to cross question him; and with a view to discredit his evidence asked him if he had not lately been in trouble? Cooke answered that his troubles or his pleasures were nothing to him: but he was perfectly ready to give the Court an exact account of the troubles to which he knew that Mingay alluded; and he then told Lord Kenyon, of the prosecution that he had suffered at Cambridge on the Report of the rascally spies. Mr. Mingay called upon him to say what the words were for which he had been prosecuted— Cooke said to him—it was something very much like what you have got under your wig— It was about a Calve’s head—upon which Lord Kenyon, and the whole Court burst into a laugh at Mingay’s expense— Some time afterwards Mingay met him walking in the Strand; stopped and spoke to him; and told him he had never in his life been put to such confusion, as by his joke about the Calve’s head.— Reeves seemed to be afraid that if he stayed longer Cooke would begin to crack his jokes upon him,
and went away. Cooke soon followed him, after taking a Passport. I went into the City, to the Counting house of the Brothers Baring, but Mr Alexander Baring was not there— They told me he would be going for Paris again next Monday. On my return I went into St. Paul’s Church, where they were performing the service of the day. The singing was excellent. The last time I had been in the Cathedral, which was in 1797. there was only one monument there, which was that of Dr. Johnson— There are now more than twenty. Executed chiefly by Flaxman, Bacon and Banks. They are for the greatest part in honour of Officers who have fallen in Battle, and there is neither Genius nor variety in the designs— The inscriptions are all in English, and all marvelously insipid, generally a bare recital that they were erected at the public expence, by a Resolution of Parliament. The monument to Howard has an inscription upon the Pedestal; not in front, but at the left side of the Statue— It begins “this extraordinary Man[”] &c, but does not give his name. It appears like the last part of an inscription, of which the first part should be on the other side— Johnson’s inscription is in Latin—well enough, excepting the notice that it was erected by a subscription of his friends, “pecunia conlata.” They might as well have inscribed the Sculptor’s Bill— I spent the Evening at home. My wife’s health continues very infirm; she sent for her old medical attendant Mr Steele, who came this Morning and whom we both consulted. Mr Birkbeck was here this morning while I was out— He is going immediately to the United States. A. H. Everett was also here; just back from Bruxelles; and intending to return to Boston in the Galen. He discovered at Bruxelles, that he could not live there with a wife upon the Salary of an American Secretary of Legation, and that Mr Eustis has no thoughts of returning home for the present— J. A. Smith took tea with Birkbeck, at Mr Cobbett’s. I received Letters from J. D. Lewis at St. Petersburg, from Jos: Hall at Gothenburg; and from C. Hughes, at Condé.

13. VI:30. There was a Meeting of the Inhabitants of Westminster, held this Morning in Palace-Yard, to Petition the Prince Regent for the removal of his present Ministers— Having occasion to walk that way, I had the curiosity to attend the Meeting for about half an hour—long enough to have my Pocket picked of my Handkerchief, and to hear detached parts of a Speech of Lord Cochrane, who repeated a joke, already many times given out at the Public Meetings—a calculation of the number of farthings given by subscription, in charity, by the principal Sinecurists and Placemen, upon the amount of the sums which they receive of the public money. There was a general laugh from the Meeting at most of the names when he announced one with twelve farthings and 56 hundredth, and so down to two farthings and a half: but the moment he named Lord Castlereagh, and before he mentioned his quota of farthings, there was an almost unanimous groan uttered, such as I never before heard; and when he had got through the whole list, there was an exclamation of “Knaves, Knaves, Knaves”—from thousands of voices at once— After Lord Cochrane, a Mr Walker spoke; but in so low a tone of voice that I could not hear a word he said. Some of the people round me, said he was mad. A vote of thanks to the high Bailiff, Arthur Morris was passed, for which he returned thanks and the meeting was dissolved. The assembly was very numerous, but they dispersed in perfect order. A Petition to the Prince was voted. I walked round and visited several second-hand Booksellers shops in search of Books for Mr Boyd’s purchase— Evening at home. J. A. Smith dined abroad and went to the play— I wrote a Letter of introduction for Mr Birkbeck, copies of which were made out for R. Rush, S. Ewing, Jos: Hopkinson, Dr S. L. Mitchill, R. King, O. Wolcott, J. Davis and Jos. Hall— Received a Letter from A. H. Everett, which he had yesterday sent out to Ealing, to give me notice of his arrival, and of his motives for returning immediately to the United States— Received also a Letter from a person named Raimbach, to recommend a foreign General Officer for a Commission in the American Army.

14. VI:30. David Baker had written a Letter to my Son John, proposing to him to come and take seats with him in a box which his mother had taken for the Oratorio this Evening, at Covent-Garden Theatre— John sent the Letter to his Mother, and referred Baker to her for an answer— I was consenting to give our three boys permission to come, but the arrangement was to be made for their lodging in town, which my wife took upon herself to settle— She was herself extremely unwell, but went out to Ealing; remained there, and sent our three Sons in the Evening into town with the Carriage— They went immediately to the Oratorio, and J. A. Smith after dining with me went and joined them there. It was midnight before they came home. My only business atchieved this day was
answering Raimbach’s Letter, and one from an old man who subscribes his name Rowet alias Rodger, and writes at Hamilton, North Britain, that he had a son named John, who went to sea many years ago, and who he has heard is now an Officer in the American Navy— He requests me to make enquiries— There was a succession of Visitors at the Office, all the Morning— Messrs. Foxall, Boyle, D’Arcy, Pinkney, Curwin of Philadelphia, General Boyd and Mr Storer. Mr Foxall, since he called to see me at Ealing last Summer, has been visiting among his old friends and acquaintance in Staffordshire, viewing the iron manufactures; preaching, in various parts of the Country; and changing his condition; that is getting married. He is now about returning to the United States, with his new companion, by the April Packet from Falmouth— Notwithstanding his preaching some of the manufacturers, though his old friends, refused to let him see their works, from the fear that he might observe, and become possessed of their improvements in machinery— He says many of the great manufacturers are irretrievably ruined, and multitudes of the workmen are starving. I called at A. H. Everett’s lodgings but he was not at them; and I ranged the Streets a couple of hours; looking up books and Catalogues, for G. Boyd’s purchase. I passed a solitary evening after dinner, reading the Newspapers brought in by George.

15. VII: I passed a Night almost sleepless; having Charles in bed with me— John was lying on the Sopha in the next chamber—about four in the Morning, I got up: gave him my place in bed, and took his on the Sopha; after which I got a couple of hours of sleep. Great part of the morning was engrossed by visitors. Dr Cooke— W. Church a man of many inventions. A. H. Everett. Mr Coles, who arranged with my Son George a party, to go and see Mr Birkbeck, at his house at Guilford— Coles goes to-morrow to Richmond where George is to join him, and whence they are to proceed on Monday to Guilford— Mr Storer and Mr Marquand were also at the Office. Marquand and Everett with his wife are going to Boston in the Galen which was to clear out this day— I walked two hours with George, and examined several Booksellers shops and Stalls— The boys dined early and went to Covent-Garden Theatre where they saw Cymbeline— Coll. Aspinwall came for a certificate to obtain payment of his pension; such as I have given him twice before— He says he has room at his Office to deposite any boxes or packages that I may wish to leave there. I dined with Mr Boddington, N. 31. Upper Brook Street, by the invitation of his partner R. Sharp, who was there. Lord and Lady Holland a Mr Allen who came with them, Mr Brougham, Mrs Alexander Baring, and a Mr Jekyl, who Mr Sharp told me was reported the wittiest man in England, constituted the company with Mr Boddington, his Son and daughter. Mrs. Siddons was invited, but sent an excuse as being indisposed. Mrs Baring brought the same Apology for her husband; Lord Erskine had a previous engagement. The party was one of the most agreeable and entertaining that I ever attended— The Conversation at table turned upon a great variety of topics, upon which Lord Holland and Mr Jekyl were extremely humorous and amusing—Literature, the fine Arts, very little politics, but personalities in great abundance— Ludicrous anecdotes, ridiculous sayings, and burlesque characteristics of many distinguished personages, known to most of the company, with no small intermixture, of satirical observation: but all in the most perfect good humour.— Lord Holland’s wit principally consisted in “taking off,” ridiculous persons, and Mr Jekyl’s in telling jocular stories, and repeating puns— Mr Brougham is not a man of wit, but has taste and learning, great information, indefatigable industry, and a moderate portion of eloquence. Much of the wit and especially of the mimicry was lost to me for want of acquaintance with the persons— The late Lords Thurlow, and Kenyon, Judge Buller, Lord Ellenborough and Justice Parke, the Poets Southey, Coleridge and Wordsworth, Dennis O’Brien, Michael Angelo Taylor, T. Tyrwhitt and General Bloomfield, the Duke of Montrose and others, names unknown to me were introduced and afforded large scope for merriment. Mr Jekyl told me that he was born in Boston, and that his father had resided there many years— The party broke up about eleven: but it was some time after twelve when the boys came home from the Play.

16. VI: A second, and this time a totally sleepless Night. I took John to bed with me, and assigned the Sopha to Charles; but I could not close my eyes. I was up two or three times in the Night but without effect— As usually happens on these occasions, I could fix my mind upon nothing. If I could make myself something to do, the time at least would pass less heavily. I rose at six and after rousing the boys left them to follow me with the Carriage which I had ordered to be at the door at eight— I then walked till they overtook me near the fourth milestone from Hyde Park Corner— We got to our house at Ealing at ten— I found Mrs Adams was much better than when she came out from town. Mr Grubb came out, and brought back my Letter-Book and Papers that he has had ever since he left my Office. He declined staying to dine. I attended Church at the afternoon Service. Mr Milman, read Prayers for the fourth Sunday in Lent, and Mr Warry preached the Sermon from Hebrews III.13. “But exhort one another daily, while it is called to day: lest any of you be hardened through the deceitfulness of sin.” I should perhaps have profited more by Mr Warry’s exhortation, after a good night’s rest. The Church was very thinly attended. The remainder of the day till dinner at six I was engaged with my journal. After dinner John and Charles returned to School— I have made an idle week of it in London; and am apprehensive I shall waste most of the time while I have two residences. The infirmity of my right hand which continues increasing threatens to disqualify me shortly for writing, almost entirely— George and Charles are still suffering with Coughs which the late hours, the Theatres and the atmosphere of London have aggravated.

17. VII: George went this Morning to Richmond where he found Mr Coles, and they proceeded upon their visit to Mr Birkbeck at Guilford. I received a Letter and Account from A. Loughnan and Co. which I answered, and a Note from Lord Castlereagh, dated yesterday, and requesting me to call at his house this or to-morrow Morning at half past eleven O’Clock. I was occupied all the Morning with my Journal which I brought up to this day. We dined at five O’Clock, and after dinner came in to London. I walked to and beyond the Kensington Turnpike, before I was overtaken by the Carriage. We reached Craven-Street about half-past eight— I read in a Volume of Woodfall’s Debates for 1795. two or three hours. Chiefly the Debates on the Treason and Sedition Bills of that time—the Precedents of those now in the process of re-enactment. Lord Harrowby alluded in his Conversation with me the other day at Count Palmella’s to that debate, and particularly to an expression of Mr Fox’s that if the Bill should pass, it would be a question not of morality but merely of prudence, with the People, whether they should or should not obey it—and to a question pointedly put to him at the third reading of the Bill, by Mr Abbott, now the Speaker of the House of Commons, whether the Bill when passed into a Law would be obeyed, or whether the standard of rebellion was then to be raised. a Question which Harrowby said had greatly annoyed Fox. I went over the whole debate this Evening, and specially marked these Speeches of Fox and Abbott— A comparison between the debates then and those at the present time strikingly illustrates the remark how tamely a Nation will bear the refixing of a yoke against which they most convulsively struggled, when first fastened upon them. There is now scarcely a voice raised against those Laws in a time of profound Peace, which Fox then pronounced so odious and oppressive that resistance against them by the People would be justifiable.

18. VI: A totally sleepless Night again. We resorted to several expedients to obtain sleep; and removed the bed to the adjoining drawing-room; but without success for myself. The principal cause of this I believe to be the smalness of the Bed-chamber and the want of a circulation of air, much aggravated by the form of the bed-curtains. After rising I wrote little, and read all the papers delivered to me by Coll. Talmadge respecting William Bedlow Crosby’s case— At half past eleven I went to Lord Castlereagh’s— After repeating apologies for having delayed so long an official communication in answer to my note of theSeptember last, which he attributed to the excessive pressure of business upon himself and upon the whole Government arising from the State of their internal affairs, he said he was at length authorized to make certain propositions to me relative to the commercial part of my proposals: the other or political part, involving so many and so extensive and complicated considerations, that the Government had not been able to come to any conclusion upon it— With regard to the intercourse between the United States and the British West-India Islands, this Government still adhered to the policy which had long been established, and were not prepared for any departure from their antient colonial policy; nor had they any complaint to make with respect to the act of Congress lately past prohibiting British Vessels from clearing out from the Ports of the United States for those Islands— They considered it merely as the exercise of a fair reciprocal right on the part of the United States, to which they could have no objection, and at which they entertained no dissatisfaction. I told him I had no information that the act had passed, but he said they had received the information— But he added that they were willing to extend the privileges of the Free-Port Act, which I had stated to be, and which really were now confined to the vessels of European Nations, to those of the United States; and also to admit them to the Island of Bermuda— And with respect to the intercourse between the United States and the British Provinces in North-America, they were willing to agree to an Article like one formerly proposed, which he read from a paper in his hand, and which seemed to me a transcript from the Treaty of 1794— He said he was not yet quite prepared, but he hoped to send me to-morrow, or perhaps in the course of this day, a Note containing all these propositions, which they would agree to, upon conditions of reciprocity, and with a view to manifest their dispositions to promote the harmony between the two Countries— I said that immediately upon receiving his Note, I should recur to my Instructions from my Government, and would submit to him the result of my observations upon his proposals— He said that if I should find it came within the extent of the Powers from my Government; so that it would not be necessary for me to refer the subject to them, he should propose to conclude the Articles as supplementary to the Convention of 3. July 1815 and to be of the same duration— I said that so far as related to the principle of reciprocity, there would
be nothing incompatible with it in the prohibitory Act of Congress, which applied only to Ports from which the vessels of the United States are excluded; and of course would immediately cease to apply to any Port that should be opened— I mentioned to him the accidents that had happened to some of the Letters and despatches addressed to me from America, by the operation of the Act of Parliament which requires that Letters brought in merchant vessels should be delivered up to be sent by the Post-Office— Lord Castlereagh did not know how the Law was, in this respect; nor did he suggest any means of removing the inconvenience. I also spoke to him concerning the case of W. B. Crosby, all the particulars of which I stated to him— I mentioned the Laws of the State of New-York confirming the claims of British Subjects to Estates liable to escheat—and told him I understood Mr Bagot had promised Crosby any assistance that he could give him to obtain restitution of the property— Lord Castlereagh said he did not know that Mr Bagot had written any thing upon the subject. That the Laws of the State of New-York were he supposed founded on the policy of the United States to encourage foreigners to speculate in our Lands, but very naturally the policy of this Country was to give no such encouragement— I spoke to him of Reeves’s pamphlets and of his doctrine that the disabilities of alienage could not apply to Citizens of the United States, and observed that Mr Crosby might perhaps want nothing more than the power to prosecute his appeal before the king in Council, which the late War only had prevented him from prosecuting— He said nothing to encourage the expectation that any thing in favour of Crosby would be done— My interview with him was of not more than half an hour; and he repeated that heretofore he had been used to devoting his Evenings to the House of Commons, and the Mornings to Foreign Affairs, but now he was obliged to employ his Mornings also to the internal affairs of the Country; being in constant and daily attendance upon two Committees— One of finance, embracing the whole system of public expenditure of the Country; and the other upon the Poor Laws— After leaving him I walked a couple of hours and visited several Booksellers shops. On returning home I found Mr A. H. Everett, who came to take leave, intending to go to morrow to embark in the Galen, at the Isle of Wight— I went with my wife and paid visits to Mr. & Mrs King, who were not at home, and to Mr Bourke, the Danish Minister and his Lady, who received us— He was engaged with his Post— She invited us to dine with them on Thursday— We took a ride in Hyde Park; and on returning home I wrote a short Letter to my Mother— Smith dined with G. Joy at Paper Buildings— We were invited to a musical party this Evening at Mrs. Cowell’s; but my wife and myself were both so unwell that we sent an excuse. I made a very short Evening.

19. VI: Mrs A. Porter sent a Note requesting the return of Sir Robert Liston’s Letter to Mr Ewart, which my wife accordingly took to her. Mr Everett called again having postponed his departure till to-morrow Morning. I walked with Mr Smith to Lackington’s Temple of the Muses in Finsbury Square. But I found the Books there not obtainable on so good terms as elsewhere. This establishment is much changed from what it formerly was, and not for the better— I received this Evening a short Note from the Under-Secretary of State in the foreign department W. Hamilton, with the Note promised yesterday by Lord Castlereagh: that is a draft of four Articles, without preliminary, conclusion or Comment. The first is for admitting American Vessels, under 30 tons burthen and having only one deck to the free-ports in the West Indies with certain specified articles of importation & exportation— The second admits American Vessels to the island of Bermuda, and the third to Turk’s Island for salt, with Liberty to export certain specified Articles— The fourth stipulates a free intercourse between the United States and those parts of the adjoining British Provinces in North America, where the division line is the middle of rivers or lakes; but excluding from the right of Navigation wherever both sides of the lake or river belong to the same party.

20. V:30. Another almost sleepless Night— The exception was of less than two hours between one and three O’Clock in the Morning. My wife also lost her sleep, and we scarcely know how to account for it. The smalness and closeness of our bed-chamber, the badness of the bed, and the situation of the house which is very low, and close upon the bank of the river, all successively occurred to us, and we concluded to look out for another house to reside in— My wife went with Smith and looked over several this Morning. I rose at half past five and immediately roused up Smith, intending to prepare a despatch to the Secretary of State, with a Copy of the Articles, received last Evening from Lord Castlereagh, in time to send them by A. H. Everett, who was to leave town at eight O’Clock. But the paper was so long that it was impossible to have the copy made out in time— Mrs Bourke, and Mrs King paid visits to Mrs Adams while she was out. G. Joy, J. Sergeant and J. M. Forbes called at the Office.— Sergeant is going immediately to France— I had about two hours of Conversation with him upon the political affairs of our Country; upon my own purpose of returning to the United States; and upon the state of the business upon which he came for the Bank of the United States, in which he has neither absolutely succeeded nor failed— I walked an hour and visited several Bookseller’s shops, but without finding any of the Articles that I wanted— Dined with my wife at the Danish Minister Mr Bourke’s— Count Palmella, and Count de Lima, also a Portuguese, the French Generals Foix and Treillemin, with
two or three other Gentlemen formed the company— Mr Crawford and Baron Just came in after dinner. I played whist after dinner with Count Palmella, Mr Crawford, Mr Bourke, Baron Just, Count de Lima and Mr Strecchi successively till Midnight. Mrs Bourke did not play— There was much talk of a Manuscript from St. Helena just published.

21. VI:45. I had a tolerable Night’s rest, but find my state of health much resembling what it was in March 1810. just seven years ago, immediately before I had the first violent attack of inflammation in the left eye. My eye has this day been weak, bloodshod, and painful— Mr and Mrs Charles King paid us a visit, with their two little daughters— They have lately returned from Paris, and are going immediately to America— Mr Sergeant and Watmough called for Passports—going next Monday. I went with my wife, and looked over a house, in Upper-Seymour Street to be let; but did not find it suitable for us. Visited various Booksellers’ shops— Smith dined abroad. George returned from his visit to Mr Birkbeck at Guilford— I partly read this Evening the Manuscript from St. Helena, which has every internal mark of authenticity.

22. VII:15. Mr. J. Reeves called at the Office and made further enquiries concerning Crosby’s case. I shewed him the Papers left with me by Coll: Talmadge— He said that as the time had elapsed for entering the appeal from the judgment of the Court in Jamaica; Crosby’s only remedy would be by a Petition of Right to the king which would bring the case before the Court of Chancery. Perhaps the Chancellor might direct an issue to be made up and tried at Law— I wrote a Letter to Mr. Gallatin, to be sent by Mr Sergeant. We had intended to go out to Ealing this Evening, but concluded to stay till to-morrow Morning. I went with my wife to Covent Garden Theatre, where we saw Cymbeline, Bombastes Furioso, and Midas— It was the first time I had ever seen the Tragedy— The part of Posthumus was performed by Booth, a very young man lately started as a rival to Kean, and who by a shuffling struggle between the two Theatres to snatch him each from the other has lately been a very conspicuous object to the public. Imogen was by Miss Foote; who has all the beauty and all the modesty of the part; but not all its enchanting sensibility— Booth has talents; but is not a very powerful actor— He was last year performing the most insignificant parts, at a Salary of two Pounds a week. This year he was brought forward not two Months since in the part of Richard the third which he performed with great success; but was announced as a mere imitator of Kean— Then the Muses of the rival Theatres pulled caps for him; and Covent-Garden obtained final possession of him— In Cymbeline he plays a part that Kean has not attempted; but is still charged as being an imitator of him— He did not strike me as such; but as an actor far inferior to Kean. He got through the part of Posthumus very well; but with faint, and not undisputed applause. The House was however full. The play itself is deficient of interest— Bombastes Furioso is a farce excessively ridiculous and laughable. Midas is a Burletta, entirely musical, and humorous enough. It was past twelve O’Clock when the Play finished— George, who had seen Cymbeline last week went this Evening to Drury-Lane, & saw Kean in Sir Giles Overreach. Smith dined with Murdoch.

23. VIII:15. We came out to Ealing this Morning. George walked with me till the Carriage overtook us in Kensington— The day was remarkably fine; but the weather has been cold and frosty all the week. It was two O’Clock when we reached home. I went to Church with George, at Evening service. Mr Milman read prayers for the fifth Sunday in Lent, and Mr Warry preached from John XVIII:37.— “To this end was I born, and for this cause came I into the world, that I should bear witness unto the truth. Everyone that is of the truth heareth my voice.” John and Charles came home and dined with us, and returned after dinner to school. I endeavoured to read one of Horsley’s Sermons, but found myself too drowsy.— Took this Morning the third draught of alternate days.

24. VIII:15. Packed up three boxes of Books. Wrote a Note to Miss Clitherow, respecting Little Boston House, and to enquire if we could without inconvenience to her, and her Sister, Lady William Seymour, keep possession of it, a few weeks longer. She answered immediately that we might keep the house as long as may suit our own convenience. I wrote Letters to A. Glennie and Son; and to James B. Church at Cork— We dined at five O’Clock; and immediately after dinner came in to London— I walked to the fourth Milestone. At Craven Street I found Letters from S. Hazard and J. Maury at Liverpool; from Coll. Aspinwall and from G. Joy. Hazard was just sailing for America. Mr Maury sends me an account of new charges against the Public, for which he pleads Coll. Aspinwall’s example— The Coll. Asks a permission from the Lords of the Treasury to despatch a vessel to Boston, with one hundred destitute American Seamen; and Mr Joy solicits my vote and interest, as a Member of the Society of Arts, for a Mr.
Tooke, who is canvassing for the Office of Vice-President of that Institution— There was also a Card from Coll. Thornton inviting Mrs Adams and me to a small party to-morrow Evening at the Duchess of Cumberland’s to meet the Prince Regent. I attempted to read, but my eyes refused to perform their Office.

25. V:30. I wrote Despatch 75 to the Secretary of State. A Note to Lord Castlereagh, asking for a permission from the Lords of the Treasury for the Consul to despatch a vessel with one hundred destitute American Seamen; and a Note to Mr Bourke the Danish Minister enquiring whether he proposed going to the Duchess of Cumberland’s party this Evening, in full dress, or in frock— This is one of those affairs, insignificant elsewhere, but of great importance at Courts. There are occasions upon which a full dress is indispensable; and others where it is disused. The line of distinction is not clear in this Country, and there is always an aukwardness in finding oneself differently garbed from the rest of the Company. My doubt in this case arose from the Card of invitation’s expressing that the party was to meet the Prince Regent. Mr Bourke answered me that he should go in frock, and that all the company he believed would do the same— Sir Robert Liston called at the Office to return Mr Smith’s visit, and without expecting to find me— Mr J. M. Buchman likewise came, and proposes to go in a few days to Liverpool, to embark for the United States— But he has also some project of staying to be presented at Court. I promised to present him at the next Levee, if he should stay— Walked an hour before dinner, and dined with Smith at Mrs A. Porter’s. My wife declined going. Sir Robert and Lady Liston, Lady Lowrie, Mr Lockhart, Mr and Mrs King, Mr Boswell, and one other Gentleman were the Company. After dinner there were several other persons came in, among whom Mr Basil Cochrane was introduced to me; and a Mr Marsh, one of the very few persons whom I have met here who knew my father at the time of his Mission in this Country. Marsh was then one of the Commissioners upon the claims of the Refugees— They sent out a Mr Anstey to America to ascertain many of the facts relative to those claims— Marsh says that upon his application, my father furnished Anstey with Letters to the Governors of the States and to his own friends, which enabled Anstey to transact his business entirely to the Satisfaction of the Commissioners and for which they were entirely indebted to my father— We came home about ten O’Clock, and shortly afterwards I went with my wife to the Duchess of Cumberland’s evening party. The Duke and almost all the men, were in frocks, but the Prince Regent himself, and several others were in full dress uniforms— Captain D’Este the Duke of Sussex’s Son told me he thought the Prince had done it by way of example, and as a hint for imitation— The party was numerous—perhaps 300 persons— The rooms crowded and very warm— There was music. The Piano, and the Opera-Singers Naldi, his daughter and Madame Camporesi. The Duke and Duchess were very attentive in going round and speaking to their Company— The Duke to the Men, & the Duchess to the Ladies. Count Fernan-Nuñez the Spanish Ambassador told us he was recalled, and appointed Ambassador to Paris. He also told us that Curtoys went off yesterday— Baron Just, the Saxon Minister invited me to dine with him to-morrow and Mr. and Mrs Bourke asked us to dine with them on Sunday— We came home about one in the Morning.

26. VI:45. Wrote a Letter to J. Maury, and two to W. C. Nicholas, late Governor of Virginia: one of introduction for Mr Birkbeck, and the other concerning W. Couling. At the Office we had this morning J. Reeves, who came to talk about Crosby’s case; Major Thayer an American Officer just from France, and on his return to the United States; and a person named Haynes, an English farmer who has determined to go to America. I had some conversation with Major Thayer, concerning the Books to be procured for the War department; and he gave me some useful information to facilitate this object. Haynes has a brother, living in New-York; a hatter who has resided there these twenty years. He himself is a farmer, with a wife and six children, and rented a farm in Shropshire, with which he says he did very well until the Peace. But since then he has been constantly losing; and the Poor Rates and Taxes, are so oppressive that he can no longer live under them— Last year he sunk at least a thousand Pounds— He gave his Landlord notice to quit; and they could not agree upon the terms of a new lease. The Land lord was willing to reduce the rent considerably, but not to the extent that he demanded— So he sold his Stock, and quitted the farm, and had determined to go and try his fortune in America. He came to ask for a Passport, which he being an Englishman I could not give him; but which I told him he would not want. He said they did throw obstacles in the way of people who wanted to go out of the Country— But he was not an artificer, but a farmer and no person could have any right to stop him. He had not finally determined whether to go from London, or from Liverpool. He had been to look at one vessel here, which he liked very well, but was afraid she would sail before he could be ready. He had offered money to the Mate who had shewed him the vessel, and had been much surprized at
his refusing to take it— My wife went to Walthamstow, to see her old friend Mr Thorpe; but did not find him at home— In my daily walk I stopped at the Bookseller Priestley’s in Holborn, and took some Books for which my father had written— I dined with Baron Just, the Saxon Minister, at N. 17. lower Brook Street. Baron Rehausen & Mr Pfeffel, the Swedish and Bavarian Ministers, Mr Hamilton the Under-Secretary of State, Mr Chester, the Assistant Master of the Ceremonies, Mr Poletica, Sir Charles Flint, and two other Gentlemen formed the Company— Poletica spoke to me of the Manuscript from St. Helena which he pronounces to be spurious— Sir Robert Liston yesterday declared himself of the same opinion— I have perhaps hastily adopted the contrary belief. Poletica told me he had seen this morning the American beauty, Mrs. R. Patterson— They have just returned from Paris— Baron Just’s Apartments were so excessively warm that I was obliged to come away almost immediately after we rose from table.

27. VI:15. Great part of the day was wasted in idleness. We had a morning visit from Mr Poletica; and Mr G. Joy called at the Office, much disconcerted at a decision which he had just been hearing by the Lords of Appeal condemning an American Vessel and Cargo with which he had some concern, and which he had confidently expected an acquittal— In my walk I continued my purchases of books for the War Department— Went with my wife and Smith to an Evening party at Mr Delafield’s— There were several Americans but the greatest part of the Company were Strangers to me. I played whist with several Gentlemen and one Lady. There was dancing. Country dances and Quadrilles— We came home between twelve and one O’Clock leaving Smith there— He came home at four— In my walk before dinner I met and spoke to Mr Goulburn.

28. VIII: Mr Birkbeck called early this Morning with his Son Richard whom he introduced to me, and to take leave; being on the point of going to Gravesend to embark for the United States, in the Ship America. All his family were already gone down in a Gravesend Boat excepting this his eldest Son, who remains here upon his farm at Guilford.— I gave him two Letters, and the first part of Bentham’s Book, the Chrestomathia, for Mr W. C. Nicholas at Richmond— Birkbeck is going with a view to settle in the United States, under the apprehension that troublous times are approaching in this Country. He mentioned a Letter from Liverpool in the Morning Chronicle, by which it appears that Cobbett is there with his two Sons, and going by the Importer to New-York. Major Thayer likewise called and brought the Catalogue of Military Books that he had promised me— Mr Meyers a young American of Norfolk, and a young Irving of New-York, came for Passports— Also a French Officer, going to the United States, to have his Passport endorsed— I received a Letter from G. W. Erving at Madrid— Wrote a Note to Lord Castlereagh, concerning the case of W. B. Crosby. Lucie Haüel who has been passing the Winter at Paris with Mrs Dunlop has returned, and came home this Morning. She went back however to Mrs Dunlop for two days. My wife came out with me this afternoon to Ealing. We came home for dinner, about seven. I walked from Turnham Green.

29. VII: Sent Antoine to London, with Cards for Wednesday to Mr and Madame Bourke, and to Baron Just— Our Sons John and Charles came home from school. George walked with me before dinner to Brentford and through Sion house Park. I had a day of leisure, which was not employed to good purpose. The double residence unsettles all my habits of occupation. I began a Letter to my father of which I wrote however but little; and some time was absorbed in copying effusions of last November, the short period of inspiration; which with all its inspiration I still regret; for it shewed how much may be done with persevering Industry, and with scarcely any waste of time.

30. VII:30. The languor and relaxation of the Spring are stealing upon me, and made me rise this Morning two hours later than I should have done. I attended Church alone— The boys went to the Chapel— Mr Carr read prayers for the sixth Sunday in Lent, or Sunday before Easter— The Service was longer than usual, and was lengthened by the Churching of a Woman, a ceremony seldom performed, for it is the first time I have witnessed it— Mr Carr gave notice that there would be Church Service every day this week and the Administration of the Communion next Friday, and Sunday— Mr Milman preached the Sermon, from Psalm XLV:4. first part of the verse— “And in thy Majesty ride prosperously, because of truth and meekness and righteousness,” which he said although it was not certain to have been prophetical of Christ’s riding into Jerusalem, might be properly so considered— This Psalm furnishes the text for several of Bishop Horsley’s Sermons, which may perhaps have tempted Mr Milman to exercise his ingenuity upon it— But it is not wise in Mr Milman to remind his hearers of Bishop Horsley.
Immediately after dinner we took John and Charles to school; and thence proceeded to London by the Acton road. At Craven Street I found Notes from Mr and Mrs Bourke, declining, and from Baron Just accepting the invitation to dinner next Wednesday— One from Count Palmella, enclosing a small Packet for Mr Correa da Serra the Portuguese Minister in the United States, to be forwarded; and one from Nunn the Bookseller, about the Collection of Parliamentary debates— A Letter from Jas. Maury at Liverpool who is going upon a short Tour, and one from Robert Jaques at the Danish island of St. Croix; enclosing a packet for Baron Rosenkrantz the Minister of foreign Affairs at Copenhagen. Jaques has been appointed Consul of the United States at St. Croix, and says he presented his Commission to His Excellency Major-General Von Bentzon, Governor of the Island, for approbation; but for want of authority was referred by him to the Government in Denmark— Bentzon has lengthened his name since he became a Governor— Between ten and eleven we went to a party at the Spanish Ambassador’s— The Prince Regent was there; and almost all the singers of the Opera— The company amounted perhaps to 300 persons. Many french and Italian Airs and duets were sung. Mr and Mrs Patterson, and the Misses Caton were there— The Ladies much noticed by the Prince Regent, and generally admired as the handsomest women there— Miss Louisa Caton, is engaged to be married to Coll. Harvey, one of the Duke of Wellington’s Aides de Camp; now with him at Paris— The Sardinian Chargé d’Affaires the Marquis de Grimaldi told me he had a Letter from Madrid; mentioning that the American Squadron had been refused admission into Port Mahon; but had gone in nevertheless; had remained there as Masters, as long as they chose, and then departed again— But it is strange that Mr Erving says nothing of this to me; in his Letter of 26. February— We came home at one A.M.

31. VII:30. A succession of visitors employed almost the whole Morning. First Major Thayer who came for an endorsement of his Passport, which was from Mr Gallatin. He is going to embark for the United States at Havre— Next General Boyd, who left with me a statement of a privilege formerly granted to him by the East-India Company, in remuneration for his services to them as a partizan Chief, to export 300 Tons of Saltpetre, from Calcutta to the United States— This Cargo was nevertheless seized at the Cape of Good Hope, and condemned by the Vice-Admiralty Court.— The Court of Appeals in England reversed this Sentence, and decreed the restoration of the property to Boyd— But a sale had been forced at the Cape, the proceeds of which left a heavy loss upon him; instead of a very large profit which he would have realized in the United States, had his Saltpetre duly arrived there. He is now therefore renewing an application to the East-India Company for a new grant of the like privilege, and with some promise of success has received an intimation advising him to apply for the sanction of the Government— He left the paper with me, not expressly asking for my interposition in his favour, but doubtless with a view of obtaining it— Mr Buchanan came for a Passport and is now going to Edinburgh for a Month, intending then to embark at Liverpool, without returning to London. Coll. Tallmadge called to consult with me upon the Affair of W. B. Crosby— I read to him the Note I had prepared to address to Lord Castlereagh on the case— Told him of the Conversations I had had with Mr Reeves relating to it, and advised him to take the opinion of some lawyer of eminence upon it— This measure he preferred however to postpone, until Lord Castlereagh shall have answered my Note— Mr Joseph Thorpe, the youngest Son of the old Gentleman whom my wife went to see last week at Walthamstow, but whom she did not find at home, came to enquire when his father could be sure of finding her. He comes usually to town on Fridays, and she fixed upon next friday fortnight. Our last visitor was Dr Tillary, a Scotchman, who after a residence of forty years in the United States came over last Summer to pay a visit to his native Country. He was an acquaintance of Smith’s and a physician of eminence and great practice at New-York. But his present tour has not yielded him the gratification he had expected. During his absence he has had the misfortune of losing his wife with whom he had lived happily, thirty-five years, and of whose death he has but very recently heard. And in Scotland he has been disappointed in his expectations— The University of Edinburgh where he was educated has lost all its eminent professors and is in a decayed and declining state— Munro is much degenerated from the abilities and merit of his father and Grandfather— Gregory is a man of talents, but a perfect bashaw— The professors of Theology have become frequenters of dancing assemblies, and card-players, and the only good instruction to be acquired at Edinburgh, is from the private Lecturers who are discouraged by the Magistrates.— The Doctor spoke with so much feeling upon all these Subjects that he was quite affecting— In my Morning walk I met and walked with Mr G. Joy, in the Temple-Garden. He is now at his nephew H. H. Joy’s rooms in the Paper Buildings. In passing through the Courts and Yards of the Temple I looked up at the windows of the chambers occupied by my friend W. V. Murray, with a melancholy recollection of the Scenes I had witnessed there at my first acquaintance with him in 1784. Mr Joy spoke to me of a rumour now revived by Articles in the Newspapers last received from New-York; one of which is copied into the Morning Chronicle of this day; purporting that I am to be recalled, with the offer of the Department of State; to which is added that Mr Clay is to be appointed to the Mission at this Court. It is however a merely unauthenticated rumour, though I have more
reason to fear than to hope it may prove well founded. Joy kept me in conversation and walking until the time came for returning home to dinner— I went with my wife and Mr Smith to an Evening party at Miss Bond’s— Her Drawing Rooms are small, and were excessively crowded, with Company. Count Palmella and the Chevalier de Freire were there. Sir Robert and Lady Liston; Coll. and Mrs Aspinwall, Mr and Mrs King; Mr and Mrs Patterson and Miss Caton, Mr W. Vaughan and his Sister, Mr G. Shaw, a Mr & Mrs Clymer of Philadelphia whom I had never seen; and many others— There was no Music, and no room for dancing. Miss Bond is going to America with Mr and Mrs King— After spending an hour there in the throng and the heat we returned home about twelve.

Day. Since our residence has been partly transferred to London there has been great entrenchment upon the regularity of my occupations— Late Evenings and late mornings; frequent visitors received; many visits to be returned and continual interruptions of business; with a proportional waste of time. The range of my rising hour through the Month has been fromthe averageMy breakfast hour ten and dining hour six as usual. An unsettled state of mind, with anxious anticipation of the future have marked a period of suspense, with alternatives all of which are cheerless; but accompanied with the hope and reliance which I never have had, and have now no reason to distrust.
